The Myth of American Exceptionalism is dead

28/06/2022

Michael Athey argues it is only America's various and prominent social justices that hold the title of exceptional.

Image by Penn Today / Creative Commons

By Michael Athey

After pouring over the works ofÂ twentieth-century AmericanÂ poet, feminist and social justiceÂ advocate badass, Adrienne Rich for myÂ dissertation, I have been left reflecting on the contemporary poignancyÂ of Richâ€™s work. America has long beenÂ heralded as a guiding light for nations.Â Belief in their exceptionalism most recently epitomised by Senator Ted CruzÂ exclaiming America is the â€œfreest, mostÂ prosperous, safest country on Earthâ€.Â Yet the juxtaposition of Cruzâ€™s statement being spoken in the wake of twenty-one people, mostly children, beingÂ massacred in an American school, hasÂ exposed the myths of American exceptionalism. Itâ€™s time to accept AmericaÂ is currently just as much in a mire asÂ it was during the 1970s socio-politicalÂ turmoil when Rich was writing.

A recently leaked draft opinionÂ from the Supreme Court of the UnitedÂ States most recently made me considerÂ the extent of America's progress. TheÂ draft in question, a repeal of a womanâ€™sÂ right to choose whether to have anÂ abortion, secured nationally throughÂ Roe v Wadeâ€™s 1973 case. Choosing toÂ end a potential life is heart-breaking.Â However, it is important to rememberÂ a womanâ€™s right to an abortion is different to enforcing an abortion. If abortion is legal, women are not requiredÂ to have abortions; it just gives them aÂ choice of acquiring one safely. In contrast, criminalising abortion doesnâ€™tÂ enforce a complete ban. Rather it removes the safe circumstances they canÂ be operated under. Legal or not, theÂ statistics for women seeking abortionsÂ is largely equal. Therefore, the situationÂ regarding abortion is simply a choiceÂ of whether we want to limit the deathsÂ of women too. It is only through abortionâ€™s legalisation and subsequent regulation further endangerment to life canÂ be avoided.

The ramifications of overturningÂ Roe V Wade is more than a matter ofÂ loss of life though, it is a re-entrenchment of patriarchal control. Here Richâ€™sÂ words leap off the page into the present. Roe V Wade took a choice aboutÂ womenâ€™s own bodies from men, whichÂ had been a historical precedent, andÂ placed it back in the hands of women.Â The soon to materialise proposal willÂ reverse what had been a major empowerment of women.

Sadly, gun control is an issue withÂ no chance of being reversed, or progressed, or any sign of change. GunÂ control is like a truck stuck in an ever-lasting, ever-gripping, ever-depressingÂ â€“ NRA sponsored â€“ mud. This is despite homicides increasing in AmericaÂ by 75 percent in the previous decade.Â Three quarters of which committedÂ with guns. Each mass shooting thatÂ now occurs causes the tires to spin, butÂ this is only an illusion of movement.Â Change remains sickeningly stagnant.

Take the most recent mass shooting in Uvalde, Texas. The second mostÂ deadly school shooting in Americaâ€™sÂ history and the reaction has remainedÂ horrifyingly predictable. We have theÂ typical thoughts and prayers paradeÂ and reanimation of politicians expressing desire for change. Yet where thereÂ was supposedly â€œseriousâ€ bipartisanÂ discussion, Uvalde has now largelyÂ been dropped from the news and political agenda. Dropped alongside theÂ equally horrifying events of Las Vegas,Â Orlando, Sandy Hook and countlessÂ others. Once again, the wheels spinning aimlessly. Americaâ€™s political eliteÂ are happy to keep their thoughts andÂ prayers on standby for the next roster ofÂ school kids.

Putting aside the evidently problematic gun lobbyâ€™s hold over Congress,Â the political discourse surrounding gunÂ control itself is indicative of the stalemate. Politicians on both sides of theÂ debate will run towards statistics toÂ support their position but fail to portray the meaning of the data. For example, I was shocked toÂ discover the repeated statistic that 70Â percent of Americans support gun control was not entirely accurate. Indeed, aÂ recent Gallup poll stated only 52 percent of Americans wanted stricter gunÂ control. The lowest desire since 2014.Â Yet, even this statistic fails to paint aÂ clear picture, as polling on gun controlÂ at large differs from opinion on specificÂ gun policies. Some states like California already have more stringent gunÂ laws in comparison to states like Texas.Â Meaning if you ask citizens from thoseÂ respective states if they want stricterÂ gun control, you end up with an alreadyÂ satisfied Californian citizen answeringÂ no, whereas a concerned Texan wouldÂ answer yes. That is where the middlingÂ 52 percent answer Gallup determinedÂ comes from. However, if you ask aboutÂ a specific gun control policy, such asÂ background checks and mental healthÂ restrictions, 80 percent are overwhelmingly in favour. Politiciansâ€™ failure to accuratelyÂ reflect the statistics surrounding theÂ popularity of gun control reforms onlyÂ continues to keep these issues stuck inÂ the mud.

Of course, a figure like DonaldÂ Trump would shout back at my commentary on Americaâ€™s abortion and gunÂ control plights that these are â€œliberalÂ eliteâ€ issues. Not related to the quietÂ ordinary working class Americans heÂ supposedly represents. This criticismÂ fails though when this group remainsÂ just as forgotten as before his term in office. Whilst wages have risen for collegeÂ graduates, and to some extent minorities too because of anti-discriminationÂ measures, since 1979 the wages forÂ the majority of Americaâ€™s workforceÂ â€“ white working-class people withoutÂ higher education â€“ have witnessed theirÂ wages decreasing. The resulting atmosphere of despair has led this group's lifeÂ expectancy through drinking and opioids to decline. Evidently, there is moreÂ wrong with America than just â€œliberalÂ eliteâ€ issues.

The reality is the problems presentÂ in America may be in some respectsÂ different to the seventies but are nonetheless just as problematic. AmericaÂ exceptionalism is dead, murdered byÂ Americaâ€™s exceptionally depressing issues waving an AR-15. It is not time toÂ grieve this myth though. Only by accepting the reality of this situation canÂ we, as Rich wrote, birth a reality different to Americaâ€™s current wreck.
